subject: Re: JUnit 4.x and support for Java 1.4
msgSnippet: Neil, Your suggestion has a spark of creativity; although I m unclear if it contemplated companies that are inside-the-container test shops. Perhaps you were
messageBody:
Neil,

Your suggestion has a spark of creativity; although I'm unclear if it
contemplated companies that are "inside-the-container" test shops.
Perhaps you were thinking of running JUnit from a 1.5 JVM redirecting
to a 1.4 application server? hhmmm ...

The development and promotion environment at a large company is very
(or "very very") prescriptive. Creativity is exercised in solving
business problems - not in configuring the environment. (Or, even in
using the latest and greatest technology.)

_Marvin


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, Neil Swingler <neil@...> wrote:
>
> Surely even if java 5 is not permitted in production code there can
be
> no harm in using it to run a unit testing tool. Indeed starting with
> java 5 features in unit tests would be a good way to practice them
> without risking all on the production code.
>
> - Neil
>
